Award.AwardTitle: Pathways of Applied Career Experiences (PACE) Science Program in Biotechnology and Chemical Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Pathways of Applied Career Experience (PACE) Science Program provides opportunities for students enrolled in the Biotechnology and Chemical Technology programs to complete internships and other applied industry experiences to supplement student learning. Partnerships with Industry Alliance Committee members are increasing student internship offerings and utilizing industry feedback to align key courses with industry needs and therefore establishing a feedback mechanism that continually improves student outcomes. Increasing internship participation rates for all students and aligning key courses with industry needs contributes highly trained entry-level employees into the local technology economy. The PACE program addresses students in need of remediation and improves the retention of all students by using Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL) activities in selected courses. POGIL activities engage students in higher levels of thinking and collaborative group learning. It is a proven pedagogy that promotes many skills employers seek: teamwork, communication, problem solving, strong work ethic, analytical approach, taking initiative, critical thinking and time management. By implementing POGIL, technology students are more active in their learning and are better equipped with useful skills to enter the workforce. The PACE Science Program allows CCM to meet the needs of the STEM economy and the alliance with local industries demonstrates the success of the project by the number of prepared technicians produced and successfully employed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PACE Science Program at CCM had two specific aims to prepare students for the workforce in the fields of Biotechnology and Chemical Technology: 1) expand experiential learning opportunities through internships with industry partners and 2) develop skills desired by employers; such as critical thinking, teamwork, communication, time management, etc.; by implementing Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL) activities into targeted courses. Through internships and POGIL pedagogy, students are able to develop their technical and non-technical skills to make them highly desired candidates for employment. 

Over the course of the two-year project, more paid internship opportunities were established. Although proposed numerous times at bi-annual meetings, industry partners were unable to create unpaid positions, even though funding was available to support the course credit for potential interns. However, all internship opportunities are open to students enrolled as chemistry, biology, biotechnology and chemical technology majors. Even though more internship opportunities were established, all of the students hired were either chemistry or biology majors. The goal was to create more opportunities for biotechnology and chemical technology students, but despite the best efforts of those involved in the project, companies ultimately decide who to hire. 

The targeted courses for the project were Elements of Biology (remedial), Elements of Chemistry (remedial), Biochemistry (elective) and Instrumental Methods of Analysis (abbreviated IMA, capstone), the courses taught by the PI and Co-PI's. At the beginning of the courses and at the end of the courses, students are surveyed and asked to evaluate their self-perceived knowledge base, technical skills, and non-technical skills. Through laboratory experiments and pedagogy incorporating POGIL activies (published or self-written activities modeled after the POGIL learning cycle), students work on learning the course content, developing their technical skills (using equipment in the laboratory), and non-technical skills (writing, oral communication, teamwork, critical thinking, time management, etc. through the POGIL activities). The overall results of the self-evaluations of the students showed improvments in their knowledge base, technical skills and non-technical skills at the end of each course compared to the beginning of each course. 

The PI and Co-PI's concluded that incorporating active learning into the classroom improved student skills and created a more active learning environment, which in return promoted student involvment in their coursework, improved grades, and reduced withdrawals from the courses. Industry partners who hired interns in the past commented that CCM students are properly prepared for oral presentations and writing reports in addition to being able to run instrumentation and use laboratory equipment. This led to the conclusion that the project not only served to improve the skills of biotechnology and chemical technology students taking these courses, but all majors as well.

The PI and Co-PI's strived to recruit more students to the technology programs. Enrollment patterns over the last five years showed a steady number of enrolled students, but a low graduation rate in the technology programs. A shift in student enrollment from biotechnology and chemical technology to biology and chemistry was observed as well. This led to the conclusion that students are seeking more associate degrees to transfer to bachelor degree programs instead of applied associate degrees (which would allow students to directly enter the workforce as technicians).
